I started this game a while ago, and even being a hardcore FromSoft glazer like I am, I thought that this game just wasn't for me. I had not put in the time to give the combat a chance, and never stopped to explore the world of this game. I was stubborn, and I was firmly rooted in my ways from other souls-likes of running through areas and not stopping to explore or to take out enemies, of using a giant hunk of metal I could barely even call a sword to brute-force my way through the games. I never blocked, I never parried, I never used spells, And I never used buffs. Besides, it was basically a Dark Souls dex build so what could I have been missing out on anyways. It was not my smartest move ever by far.

After not playing this game for quite a long time, and playing other games with my friends, I decided that i should come back to this game. I figured I should give it another chance, after all people say it's one of FromSoftware's best games, and I never hated it when i played it, besides it cant hurt to give it another chance. And the experience was pretty good when I started it back up. I don't know when it happened but at some point in my play-through this game grabbed me, I don't know if it was the voice acting and writing, or the masterfully crafted level design, or the combat which I know consider to be the best in all of gaming, but something got me hooked. I was so into this game i wouldn't stop playing it. Every free second was time to play Sekiro, every day I woke up there was a new boss to beat. I was hooked, in a way I had never been on a game before.

It has been 7 days since I beat this game, seven days of an empty feeling that simply expresses how nothing will ever measure up to the quality of this game. No matter how many of the "Best games of all time" I play, nothing will ever measure up. nothing will ever capture me in the same way that this game did. Don't get me wrong, I will always love the souls games as the games that changed my life, and I will always remember those classic Nintendo DS games which shaped my childhood, but something here, something feels different. not simply good because of how fondly I remember it and the console it was on, its not good because it was a stepping stone to something greater, but because of something that I believe cannot be named. The absolute masterpiece that this game is, is something which cannot be put into words and can only be understood once you watch those end credits roll, and look back on the days, weeks, even months, spent in this game. If you are a fan of the souls genre, or even of video games as a whole, play it.

"Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice - A Masterclass in Gloriously Dying Over and Over Again"

Playing "Sekiro" is like enrolling in a prestigious ninja academy where the only lesson plan is "How to Die in Style." From the moment you step into its beautifully brutal world, you'll be treated to a non-stop buffet of epic boss fights and perfectly timed humiliations. But fear not—each death is just a stepping stone to becoming the shinobi god you were always meant to be.

The combat is so tight and satisfying, you’ll start parrying your morning coffee spills and trying to Mikiri Counter your cat's sudden pounces. And when you finally take down that boss who’s been turning you into digital sushi for hours, the victory dance you’ll do would make even the most disciplined samurai proud.

In short, "Sekiro" is the ultimate test of skill, patience, and your ability to laugh at your own relentless demise. It’s the most fun you’ll ever have getting repeatedly pummeled by a giant, immortal ape.

10/10 would die again!

My first introduction into a Souls games - and I can say, it didn't disappoint one bit. 

Absolute masterpiece of a game! Where 300gb of your storage isn't sacrificed in order to experience such a story rich, graphically beautiful, and satisfying combat game. It's definitely a tough game, but worth the play through. My only issue is there is a lacklustre of bosses, but contradicted by the awesome, wide spectre of bosses you do encounter. 

In Sekiro, you cant use summons, you can't change your build to combat and counter different bosses, and you can't use OP weapons or spells. All you have is your one katana, a handful of items, and whole lotta skill. That's what makes Sekiro so special. It's definitely the hardest souls game, but at the same time, it's fair, interesting and satisfying. The whole game is a pure skill check, and if you mastered Sekiro, then the other souls games shouldn't be too rough of an experience

This game is amazing, just like every other souls game out there to date. I recommend it to those who enjoy a challenge and learning the games mechanics as these games require that you at least are competent. Not only that but these games have an amazing story that can easily steal your life away. Generally in modern gaming industry it's hard to find good crafted games, and while these game are not prefect, are are damn close! 

However if you are expecting the same treatment as the other souls game this one is very different, the combat got a whole rework, focusing around parring, deflecting and guarding. The game can be completed without using this new mechanics though i won't recommend that, as learning the timing of bosses is hard yes but not as hard as people used to say it was cause they just came out of DS3 are used to rolling everything. And within this game, it has tons a ways to express yourself in combat but unfortunately not in it's RPG mechanics. As the game is much more story heavy then most before it, your character is Wolf a Shinobi and the story it tell with your character along the way through Ashina. It's a story i won't miss and gamplay is so addicting once learned or even mastered!

Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice - A Disappointing Departure from FromSoftware's Mastery

As a die-hard fan of FromSoftware's previous titles I've found myself fighting boss after boss, learning and loving the experience. I've immersed myself in the rich, interconnected worlds that the studio is known for. However, Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice stands as a stark departure from what I've come to love about their games. Despite its critical acclaim, I found it to be a frustrating and unengaging experience.

Combat: More Tedious Than Challenging

One of the biggest disappointments in Sekiro is its combat. While FromSoftware games are known for their challenging yet rewarding combat systems, Sekiro’s mechanics felt both stale and monotonous. The game demands precision, but the execution often boils down to spamming the light attack button for extended periods, waiting for the boss to counter so you can engage in the repetitive cycle of attack and deflect. This pattern, rather than feeling strategic, became mind-numbing.

Adding to this, many bosses in Sekiro tend to retreat during fights, which resets their posture bar, undoing much of the progress you've painstakingly made. Chasing them down doesn't always work effectively, and it breaks the flow of combat, turning what should be an intense duel into a tedious game of tag.

A World That Fails to Inspire

Sekiro's world is undeniably beautiful, with a strong aesthetic rooted in Japanese history and mythology. Yet, despite its visual appeal, the map felt bland and uninspired in its design. The sense of discovery and wonder that defines FromSoftware’s other games is sorely lacking here. Instead of eagerly exploring the world, I found myself moving from one area to the next out of obligation rather than curiosity.

Exploration is further dampened by the game's loot system. Like in other FromSoft games, most items you find are underwhelming or downright useless. However, unlike those games, Sekiro's streamlined progression system makes these items feel even less impactful. The few valuable items are often hidden behind illogical or obscure mechanics, leaving little reason to thoroughly explore the world.

A Mind-Numbing Grind

The most damning issue for me was how the game managed to turn challenging encounters into a grind. In previous FromSoftware titles, every death felt like a learning experience, a step closer to mastery. In Sekiro, however, I found myself zoning out during boss fights, mindlessly repeating the same actions until I finally won. The sense of achievement that usually accompanies victory in these games was replaced by a feeling of relief that the ordeal was over, followed quickly by dread at the thought of the next inevitable boss.

Conclusion

Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice is a game that simply doesn’t resonate with me, despite my deep appreciation for FromSoftware's other titles. The combat, while difficult, lacks the depth and satisfaction of their previous systems. The world, though beautiful, fails to invite exploration. And the overall experience, instead of being engaging and rewarding, felt like a tedious grind. While I respect the craftsmanship that went into Sekiro, it’s a game I found more frustrating than fun—a rare miss from a developer that usually sets the standard for excellence.

This game is one of my favorite's of all time. It's in my top 5 games of all time. I have never been a dark souls guy. played dark souls 3 and Elden Ring but never beat them due to them honestly being too difficult. But realizing I could grind souls in those games and come back to those bosses made me understand why people think this game is harder than the rest. This game requires you to master the craft of the blade, the whole game is a training ground for the last couple boss fights. in dark souls titles I never felt like I owned a boss or felt that accomplished afterwards. yeah it feels nice to finally defeat them after endless attempts. But I felt like if I had to do it again I''d probably loose a couple times before I'd beat them once more. In Sekiro I mean man do I feel like a bad ass. I mean the parrying, the dodging, the attacking everything flows within these fights and you feel like you are an actual Shinobi who has trained his whole life to defeat these enemies. Other titles I just feel like a peasant that needs to gather some broken items and get gear that makes me unmatched. But this...... Words cant describe the first feeling you get when it clicks, and honestly when it does the game isn't easy but you start to understand why you lost that fight instead of rolling around until the enemy is open to an attack. Nah I stand toe toe with these dudes and we battle like men. That's the feeling this game gives, that's the feeling I want from a game. Don't waste my time with what build I should go down or where to spec my souls into "should I build knowledge oh maybe strength. Fuck that give me a sword and watch what I do to this fucking ape. This is just completely different than any other souls game they put out. Not to mention a very easy story to follow. I couldn't tell you wtf happens in dark souls and I've tried to understand it. This game has different pathways different endings. I mean all that on top of one of the best game-plays you can find. This game solely made me want to try Elden ring again and probably gonna try the other souls games afterwards. I know they are nothing like this game. But that's how good this game is. It opened my mind to the other souls like. If you honestly don't like this game its because you were expecting a souls game where you can create a build and cheese bosses or xp farm (*cough, pussy) and then wanted to fight a boss. That's it. What other reason is there. the story is decent enough for a souls game (I think its pretty solid but not the best out there) the game play is pretty flawless (I don't think it gets much better) and visually it hold its own with Elden ring (in my opinion better but I'll let you Elden nerds have it since its open world oooooo). Come play a real game. Sekiro.....Where boys turn into Shinobi's

I enjoyed my time playing Sekiro. It is a very interesting story and very straightforward compared to other Miyazaki games.

Pluses:
- A very interesting story with a few different endings that you are able to get easily (well most of them, true ending is the hardest one)
- A very dynamic and fun gameplay
- A lot of tools that can help you in combat
- A very pretty locations
- Interesting and challenging bosses
- Emma :3
- Very interesting "boss rush" mode with unique end game boss with new moveset

Minuses:
- Demon of Hatred and Guardian Ape with the broken hitboxes (hate those guys)
- Not very obvious way to get to the true ending. But thats just a typical FromSoftware thing.

Overall I enjoyed my time in Medieval Japan with a fantasy elements and I would hope that this story would continue. But knowing Miyazaki that might be an issue.
Overall 9 Silent Wolf Shoguns out of 10 just because damn Demon of Hatred and Guardian Ape exist.
